content: Rose danios display their most vibrant colors when they are in their ideal environment.
It's a giant alright.

A peppermint angelfish at its peak value could fetch the price of an entire villa?!

When angered, pao puffers puff up like a balloon.
I heard they use bombers to stock rainbow trout in rivers.
As the red-line torpedo barb matures, its nature changes, becoming an aggressive fish that will actively attack smaller fish.

What a catch! My first... shadow in the water?
...It's a <style=Highlight>shadow bass</style>!

Fireflies can control how bright they glow.
Orchid mantises don't necessarily live on orchids.
People who've kept white cloud minnows always say they're quite the hungry little fellows.

During spawning season, sockeye salmon make their grand journey from the ocean back to the rivers.
The regal tang uses its bright yellow tail to anchor itself to coral.

The honey bees' "honey factory" follows a very strict hierarchy.

The fact that the ocean-dwelling golden pinecone fish resembles the land-grown pineapple is just a wondrous coincidence of nature.

What a catch! My first <style=Highlight>six-rayed star</style>! It has six arms.

The pink square anthias isn't just pretty to look at â€” it's good eating too!
Phew... What a catch! It's a rare <style=Highlight>ornate angelfish</style>!
The golden wonder killifish has a disproportionately large mouth.
Only mature phoenix barbs "blush."

What a catch! My first <style=Highlight>heart cockle</style>! It's got love written all over it.

What a catch! My first... bird feather?
...It's a <style=Highlight>silk moth</style> with feathery antennae!
The jade baron is like nature's own ink painting.
The fire eel swims along, trailing sparks in its wake... but no bolts of electricity!
What a catch! It's a gem-like <style=Highlight>pink square anthias</style>!
Where might the deepsea luminous spiny hatchetfish lead us to?

What a catch! My first crimson-tipped...?
...It's a <style=Highlight>crimson tip butterfly</style>!
The elephant hawk moth isn't called that because it resembles a hawk, but because it's a hawk moth that's more elephant than hawk!
The beautiful forest caterpillar hunter also happens to be a ruthless "killer."
What a catch! My first <style=Highlight>mosquitofish</style>! It doesn't just eat mosquitoes.
What a catch! My first <style=Highlight>fire eel</style>! It looks just like a regular eel.
Would the shadow-loving shadow bass ever meet the sunny bream?
The canary wrasse is small, but its "tusks" are a force to be reckoned with.
What a catch! My first <style=Highlight>phoenix barb</style>! It's got red cheeks.
What a catch! My first <style=Highlight>moon crab</style>! It can burrow into sand in a flash.

The blue blanquillo likes to stir up "sandstorms" on the ocean floor.
It's called an ornate angelfish because it's "ornate"! Sometimes naming things is just that simple.
What a catch! My first dreamy blue <style=Highlight>Yellowback Demoiselle</style>!

What a catch! My first <style=Highlight>golden puffer</style>! It's all shiny now.

What a catch! My first <style=Highlight>canary wrasse</style>! It's got "boar tusks."
Some leaves might actually be bluebottle chrysalises in disguise.
Despite having "sword" in its name, the five-bar swordtail is actually pretty gentle.
What a catch! My first <style=Highlight>rainbow trout</style>! And it's actually rainbow-colored.
The golden trout is actually just a golden-colored rainbow trout!
Phew... What a catch! It's a rare <style=Highlight>sockeye salmon</style>!
Sound waves traveling through water can disorient the large yellow croaker.
Among a school of whitetail dascyllus, there's always one that's notably bigger than the rest.
What a catch! My first <style=Highlight>sanke koi</style>! It brings good luck!
Phew... What a catch! It's the elusive <style=Highlight>honeycomb stingray</style>!

The butterfly dragonfly flies like a butterfly.
What a catch! My first oval <style=Highlight>sunny bream</style>!
The blackspot tuskfish's "buck teeth" make sea urchins go *crunch* when they munch!
It looks like it's rowing through the water with its fin movements!
The red-breasted wrasse looks similar to the harlequin tuskfish, so sometimes people call it the "imposter harlequin tuskfish."
What a catch! My first <style=Highlight>bean-shaped fist crab</style>! Gloves on, ready to throw pincers!

What a catch! My first <style=Highlight>grass carp</style>! It's not strictly vegetarian.

They say if you put a catfish among a school of green pilchard, they'll become more active.
With its special beak-like mouth, the blue trim parrotfish tears through coral like potato chips.
What a catch! My first <style=Highlight>red-breasted wrasse</style>! It's got sexy lips.
Phew... What a catch! It's a rare <style=Highlight>red spotted porcelain crab</style>!
Do coffee clearwing moths drink coffee?
They may be able to lay eggs in space, but they won't last long in polluted water.
Juvenile emperor angelfish don't have blue and yellow stripes, only white rings.

...It's a <style=Highlight>rainbow porgy</style>!
What a catch! My first <style=Highlight>royal angelfish</style>! It's got a spiny posterior fin.

The constable butterfly's "electric glow" comes from the scales on its wings, not actual electricity.

It's absolutely enormous! A plump, mighty fruit, shining with a glow of its own.
